Award.AwardTitle: Statistical Modeling, Adjustment and Inference for Seasonal Time Series
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project studies novel inference procedures and models for seasonal time series. The results of this research will have direct impact on the diagnostics of seasonal adjustment procedures that are currently implemented at the U.S. Census Bureau and other domestic or foreign agencies where seasonal adjustments are routinely published. The "Visual Significance" method used at the Census Bureau lacks a rigorous statistical justification and the new spectral peak detection methods will help to quantify type I and II errors in a disciplined fashion for a wide class of processes. Although motivated by research problems at Census, the new methodology and models are expected to be useful in the analysis of time series from various disciplines, including economics, astronomy, environmental science, and atmospheric sciences, among others.

Specifically, the project consists of three interrelated parts. In the first part, the PI will develop two new methods of spectral peak detection, which are intended to provide more principled approaches to the "Visual Significance" method used at the U.S. Census Bureau. In the second part, the PI will address the band-limited goodness-of-fit testing using the integral of the square of the normalized periodogram. Instead of assuming the strong Gaussian-like assumption as done in the literature, the PI will use a new Studentizer, so that the limiting distribution of the self-normalization-based test statistic is pivotal under less stringent assumptions. In the third part, the PI will study a new parametric class of spectral density, which can be used in model-based seasonal adjustment to improve the quality of model fitting and seasonal adjustment. The new parametric models and related model-based seasonal adjustment, if successfully developed, may offer a more effective means of modeling and adjusting time series. The research will promote teaching and training through mentoring of undergraduate and graduate students and through the development of related lecture notes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During this funding cycle (2014-2017), the PI has developed a few useful statistical methods that can be used to  analyze time series with seasonality, weak dependence, heteroscedasticity and nonstationarity among others. On one hand, a new studentization method, the so-called self-normalization has been advanced into several important inference problems, such as inference of slope parameter in linear regression models with trend regressor and errors with weak dependence and heteroscedasticity, construction of pointwise confidence interval for nonparametric time series models, inference of time series with right censoring. On the other hand, the PI has developed new bootstrap techniques for irregularly spaced time series  and for massive data, the latter of which can achieve certain statistical efficiency under computational constraints. Additionally, the PI has also investigated the coverge bound problem for both blockwise empirical likelihood method and subsampling in the time series setting, and proposed remedies to alleviate the coverage bound problem that could limit the use of these methods.

Time series with seasonality, heteroscedasticity and nonstationarity  occur in various fields, including atmosphere science, environmental science, geophysics,  hydrology, economics, finance and others. During the funding period, the PI has developed systematic inference methods for such time series. One of the features of the proposed self-normalization methodology is that it does not involve any tuning parameters or contain less number of tuning parameters than the existing procedures, and is relatively convenient to implement in practice. The new bootstrap methods are rather nonparametric and they apply to a wide range of data generating processes.    A rigorous theory accompanies most of the
proposed methodology and it shows that the proposed methods lead to more accurate inference, which is also confirmed via simulations. The project has significant impact on education through involvement of
several Ph.D students directly into the proposed research and incorporation of results into an advanced graduate level course the PI taught.The PI has also disseminated  research results by publishing them at top statistics and econometrics journals, and presenting different parts of the research at a number of conferences and department seminars.
